titleStmt.title: TO THE GREAT TETRAGRAMMATON, LORD PARAMOVNT OF HEAVEN AND EARTH: His Humble Servant dedicates him∣selfe, and implores the Enfran∣chising of his Muse.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: TO THE GREAT TETRAGRAMMATON, LORD PARAMOVNT OF HEAVEN AND EARTH: His Humble Servant dedicates him∣selfe, and implores the Enfran∣chising of his Muse.

monogr.title: Divine poems : containing the history of Ionah. Ester. Iob. Sampson. Sions sonets. Elegies. Written and newly augmented, by Fra: Quarles
monogr.author: Quarles, Francis

div.head: TO THE GREAT TETRAGRAMMATON, LORD PARAMOVNT OF HEAVEN AND EARTH: His Humble Servant dedicates himselfe, and implores the Enfranchising of his Muse.

lg.l: GReat God th'indebted praises of thy glory,
If Man shold smother, or his Muse wax faint
To number forth; the stones wold make complaint,
And, not without iust reason, say,
Mens hearts are more obdure than they.
Dismount from Heaven (O thou diviner Power)
Handsell my slender Pipe, breath (thou) upon it,
That it may run an everlasting Sonnet,
Which envious Time may not devoure:
Oh, let it sing to After-dayes
(When I am Dust) thy louder Praise.
Direct the footsteps of my sober Muse
To tread thy glorious path: For be it knowne,
She only seeks thy Glory, not her owne,
If otherwise, O! may she never
Sing more, but be strucke dumbe for ever.
